During this time, the emperor was .Nussbaum, "Kōmei Tennō," p. 553. The nengō Tenpō means "Ten Thousand Years Prolonged"Pollack, David. (2002). Reading Against Culture: Ideology and Narrative in the Japanese novel, p. 208. ==Events of the Man'en era== * 1860 (Man'en 1): First Western professional photographer to live in Japan was Orrin Freeman in Yokohama.Hannavy, John. (2007). Encyclopedia of Nineteenth-century Photography, Vol. 1, p. 770. * 1860 (Man'en 1): First diplomatic mission from modern Japan to the United States.Press release: "First Japanese Diplomatic Mission to U.S. Is Subject of May 24 Lecture," Library of Congress, April 16, 2010; retrieved 2011-12-14. ==Related pages == * Edo period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" Link to historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Keichō 1st 2nd 1860 1861 Preceded by: Ansei Era or nengō: Man'en Succeeded by: Bunkyū Category:Japanese eras Category:1860 establishments in Asia Category:1860s establishments in Japan Category:1861 disestablishments Category:1860s disestablishments in Japan
title: Man'en
